articles.headline: High Winds, Then Premiums
articles.snippet: Along the coast from Texas to Maine, insurance costs are doubling or tripling as part of continuing fallout from Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: Along the coast from Texas to Maine, insurance costs are doubling or tripling as part of continuing fallout from Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORANGE BEACH, Ala. — Add this to the list of reasons real estate is cooling off in some of the hottest markets: soaring insurance costs.

articles.headline: Stricter Voting Laws Carve Latest Partisan Divide
articles.snippet: Democrats say Republicans are trying to suppress the votes of minorities, the poor and the elderly by requiring documentation at the polls.
articles.abstract: Democrats say Republicans are trying to suppress the votes of minorities, the poor and the elderly by requiring documentation at the polls.
articles.lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — Eva Charlene Steele, a recent transplant from Missouri, has no driver’s license or other form of state identification. So after voting all her adult life, Mrs. Steele will not be voting in November because of an Arizona law that requires proof of citizenship to register.

articles.headline: Qaeda Operative Is Killed in Iraq
articles.snippet: Omar al-Faruq engineered a brazen escape from a high-security U.S. prison in Afghanistan last year.
articles.abstract: Omar al-Faruq engineered a brazen escape from a high-security U.S. prison in Afghanistan last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Sept. 25 — A senior operative of Al Qaeda who brazenly escaped from a high-security American prison in Afghanistan last year was killed Monday in a predawn raid by British soldiers in a quiet, wealthy neighborhood in southern Iraq, an American official and an official in Basra said.

articles.headline: Tobacco Makers Lose Key Ruling on Latest Suits
articles.snippet: The decision raises the possibility that cases involving light cigarettes will become a major legal threat to the tobacco industry.
articles.abstract: The decision raises the possibility that cases involving light cigarettes will become a major legal threat to the tobacco industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a legal blow to the tobacco industry, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often promoted as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim as a class-action suit.
articles.byline: By David Cay Johnston and Melanie Warner

articles.headline: Europe Panel Faults Sifting of Bank Data
articles.snippet: The panel has doubts about the legality of a U.S. antiterrorism program monitoring financial transactions.
articles.abstract: The panel has doubts about the legality of a U.S. antiterrorism program monitoring financial transactions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 — A European Union panel has serious doubts about the legality of a Bush administration program that monitors international financial transactions, the group’s leader said Monday, and plans to recommend tighter controls to prevent privacy abuses.

articles.headline: Redstone Takes a Cut in His Salary
articles.snippet: Viacom said Sumner M. Redstone was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest.
articles.abstract: Viacom said Sumner M. Redstone was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: In yet another effort to restore investor confidence, Viacom said yesterday that its chairman and controlling shareholder, Sumner M. Redstone, was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest and to base it on the company’s financial performance.

articles.headline: Homes Post Price Drop for August
articles.snippet: The last time prices fell from their year-earlier level was in April 1995, but the market slide might be beginning to ease.
articles.abstract: The last time prices fell from their year-earlier level was in April 1995, but the market slide might be beginning to ease.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home prices fell in August compared with a year earlier, the first such decline in more than a decade.

articles.headline: G.M. Said to Be Wary of Alliance
articles.snippet: General Motors has raised doubts about a three-way alliance with Renault and Nissan Motor, a senior executive at Renault said.
articles.abstract: General Motors has raised doubts about a three-way alliance with Renault and Nissan Motor, a senior executive at Renault said.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 25  General Motors has raised doubts in its talks with Renault of France and Nissan Motor of Japan that a three-way alliance would yield the benefits that Renault and Nissan insist would result from such an agreement, a senior executive at Renault said tonight.

articles.headline: Wireless Networking May Soon Get Faster. Will Anyone Care?
articles.snippet: While companies are promoting fourth-generation wireless as the next wave in Internet access, its future is far from certain.
articles.abstract: While companies are promoting fourth-generation wireless as the next wave in Internet access, its future is far from certain.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHEJU, South Korea — On this volcanic island at the tip of the Korean Peninsula, where kings once exiled dissidents and tourists now flock to casinos, South Korean engineers recently unveiled a prototype of a wireless network that they hope will revolutionize Internet access.

articles.headline: Europe Panel Faults Sifting of Bank Data
articles.snippet: A European Union panel has serious doubts about the legality of a Bush administration program that monitors international financial transactions, the group's leader said Monday, and plans to recommend tighter controls to prevent privacy abuses.   ...
articles.abstract: A European Union panel has serious doubts about the legality of a Bush administration program that monitors international financial transactions, the group's leader said Monday, and plans to recommend tighter controls to prevent privacy abuses.     ''We don't see the legal basis under the European law, and we see the need for some changes,'' said Peter Schaar, a German official who leads the panel, in a telephone interview. The group is to deliver a final report this week in Brussels, and Mr. Schaar said he expected it to conclude that the program might violate European law restricting government access to confidential banking records.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 - A European Union panel has serious doubts about the legality of a Bush administration program that monitors international financial transactions, the group's leader said Monday, and plans to recommend tighter controls to prevent privacy abuses.

articles.headline: Wireless Networking May Soon Get Faster. Will Anyone Care?
articles.snippet: On this volcanic island at the tip of the Korean Peninsula, where kings once exiled dissidents and tourists now flock to casinos, South Korean engineers recently unveiled a prototype of a wireless network that they hope will revolutionize Internet...
articles.abstract: On this volcanic island at the tip of the Korean Peninsula, where kings once exiled dissidents and tourists now flock to casinos, South Korean engineers recently unveiled a prototype of a wireless network that they hope will revolutionize Internet access.      In August, Samsung, the South Korean electronics company, gave the first public demonstration of its version of the network. One day, the company and others in the industry hope, the network will let users open a laptop anywhere and, without attaching a cable or looking for a Wi-Fi hot spot, immediately surf the Internet or download music and movies as fast as the fastest broadband.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHEJU, South Korea - On this volcanic island at the tip of the Korean Peninsula, where kings once exiled dissidents and tourists now flock to casinos, South Korean engineers recently unveiled a prototype of a wireless network that they hope will revolutionize Internet access.

articles.headline: Qaeda Operative Is Killed in Iraq
articles.snippet: A senior operative of Al Qaeda who brazenly escaped from a high-security American prison in Afghanistan last year was killed Monday in a predawn raid by British soldiers in a quiet, wealthy neighborhood in southern Iraq, an American official and a...
articles.abstract: A senior operative of Al Qaeda who brazenly escaped from a high-security American prison in Afghanistan last year was killed Monday in a predawn raid by British soldiers in a quiet, wealthy neighborhood in southern Iraq, an American official and an official in Basra said.     About 250 soldiers wearing night-vision goggles and carrying specially equipped rifles stormed a house in the Junainah neighborhood of Basra, intending to capture the operative, whom the spokesman for the British military in Iraq identified as Omar al-Faruq, an Iraqi. They were fired upon as they entered, and shot back, killing Mr. Faruq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Sept. 25 - A senior operative of Al Qaeda who brazenly escaped from a high-security American prison in Afghanistan last year was killed Monday in a predawn raid by British soldiers in a quiet, wealthy neighborhood in southern Iraq, an American official and an official in Basra said.

articles.headline: G.M. Said to Be Wary of Alliance
articles.snippet: General Motors has raised doubts in its talks with Renault of France and Nissan Motor of Japan that a three-way alliance would yield the benefits that Renault and Nissan insist would result from such an agreement, a senior executive at Renault sai...
articles.abstract: General Motors has raised doubts in its talks with Renault of France and Nissan Motor of Japan that a three-way alliance would yield the benefits that Renault and Nissan insist would result from such an agreement, a senior executive at Renault said tonight.     Patrick Pelata, who is leading the talks for the Renault-Nissan side, said he believed that his side had made a strong case in favor of a deal, which he said could help G.M. fend off a strong challenge from Toyota, which ranks No. 2 behind G.M. worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 25 - General Motors has raised doubts in its talks with Renault of France and Nissan Motor of Japan that a three-way alliance would yield the benefits that Renault and Nissan insist would result from such an agreement, a senior executive at Renault said tonight.

articles.headline: Tobacco Makers Lose Key Ruling on Latest Suits
articles.snippet: In a legal blow to the tobacco industry, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often promoted as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim as a class-action suit. ...
articles.abstract: In a legal blow to the tobacco industry, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often promoted as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim as a class-action suit.      Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn found ''substantial evidence'' that the manufacturers knew that light cigarettes were at least as dangerous as regular cigarettes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a legal blow to the tobacco industry, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often promoted as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim as a class-action suit.
articles.byline: By David Cay Johnston and Melanie Warner

articles.headline: Redstone Takes a Cut in His Salary
articles.snippet: In yet another effort to restore investor confidence, Viacom said yesterday that its chairman and controlling shareholder, Sumner M. Redstone, was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest and to base it on the compa...
articles.abstract: In yet another effort to restore investor confidence, Viacom said yesterday that its chairman and controlling shareholder, Sumner M. Redstone, was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest and to base it on the company's financial performance.      Over all, Viacom, the giant media company that owns MTV and Paramount Pictures, said Mr. Redstone's salary would be reduced starting in 2007 to $1 million from $1.75 million, his $1.3 million in deferred compensation would be eliminated and a bonus paid if certain targets are met would be reduced to $3.5 million, from $6.1 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: In yet another effort to restore investor confidence, Viacom said yesterday that its chairman and controlling shareholder, Sumner M. Redstone, was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest and to base it on the company's financial performance.

articles.headline: Stricter Voting Laws Carve Latest Partisan Divide
articles.snippet: Eva Charlene Steele, a recent transplant from Missouri, has no driver's license or other form of state identification. So after voting all her adult life, Mrs. Steele will not be voting in November because of an Arizona law that requires proof of ...
articles.abstract: Eva Charlene Steele, a recent transplant from Missouri, has no driver's license or other form of state identification. So after voting all her adult life, Mrs. Steele will not be voting in November because of an Arizona law that requires proof of citizenship to register.     ''I have mixed emotions,'' said Mrs. Steele, 57, who uses a wheelchair and lives in a small room in an assisted-living center. ''I could see where you would want to keep people who don't belong in the country from voting, but there has to be an easier way.''
articles.lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. - Eva Charlene Steele, a recent transplant from Missouri, has no driver's license or other form of state identification. So after voting all her adult life, Mrs. Steele will not be voting in November because of an Arizona law that requires proof of citizenship to register.

articles.headline: High Winds, Then Premiums
articles.snippet: Add this to the list of reasons real estate is cooling off in some of the hottest markets: soaring insurance costs.     Along the coast from Texas to Maine, owners of apartments and houses are being charged huge increases in premiums -- in some ca...
articles.abstract: Add this to the list of reasons real estate is cooling off in some of the hottest markets: soaring insurance costs.     Along the coast from Texas to Maine, owners of apartments and houses are being charged huge increases in premiums -- in some cases more than 10 times what they paid last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORANGE BEACH, Ala. - Add this to the list of reasons real estate is cooling off in some of the hottest markets: soaring insurance costs.

articles.headline: Homes Post Price Drop for August
articles.snippet: Home prices fell in August compared with a year earlier, the first such decline in more than a decade.     The August price data came with a report issued yesterday by the National Association of Realtors that showed further evidence of deteriorat...
articles.abstract: Home prices fell in August compared with a year earlier, the first such decline in more than a decade.     The August price data came with a report issued yesterday by the National Association of Realtors that showed further evidence of deterioration in the housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home prices fell in August compared with a year earlier, the first such decline in more than a decade.
